Two U.S. ships struck Iraqi mines while allied land forces stepped up artillery barrages and cut lanes for armored vehicles through the twin sand-and-rock berms that mark the Saudi border with Kuwait. A1
Army's commander in gulf is sidelined for surgery A6

Military analysis: The skirmishes along the Saudi border and inside Iraq are part of an allied effort to gain battlefield intelligence and con fuse Iraq about the main points of an attack, Pentagon officials say. A7

Interrogation of Iraqi war prisoners reveals a portrait of battle-weary front-line forces who in many cases are hungry, demoralized and bitter about fighting a war few soldiers support, intelligence officers say. A7

Children with fathers in the gulf war are consumed by events in Saudi Arabia. Near a Marine base in California, they draw bloody pictures of Saddam Hussein and miss school so their mothers won't be alone. A8
Aid from Congress to help soldiers deal with economic hardships at home may be approved soon as legislators rush to provide benefits to troops in the Persian Gulf. A12

Business people are traveling again after a month of avoiding trips because of the war, raising international airlines' hopes that business will steadily improve. D1 International A3-5, A10-11

Two bombs were set off in London at railroad stations, killing one man and wounding 40. The police were quick to blame the Irish Republican Army, which fired a mortar attack on 10 Downing Street 11 days ago. A1

Prices in the Soviet Union will rise no less than 60 percent under the Kremlin's latest plan to revive the critically troubled economy. The plan affects all but three Soviet necessities: medicine, fuel and vodka. A1

Chicago's politics have calmed down since the election of Mayor Richard M. Daley, the son of the longtime Democratic boss. He has brought stability to the fractious city and is favored for re-election. A1

The tar of the savings and loan crisis, fairly or unfairly, is clearly upon the bankers. And as a result, the prospects for the kind of sweeping reform and innovation bankers say they need do not appear at all bright. D1

Public concern about chemical waste prompted Texas to temporarily ban development of new commercial hazardous-waste sites and stop expansions of existing ones. It is the first state with such regulations. A12
A bill to protect abortion rights if the United States Supreme Court shouldrestrict them was approved by the Maryland House and then signed into law by the Governor. A15

The two-year term for governors is again under debate in Vermont and Rhode Island. Some argue that governors barely take office before a new campaign begins. Others say it keeps leaders close to the people. A15

Municipal contracts waste millions in New York City because of a lack of competition in bidding for goods and services, experts say. Sparse competition can mean poor service, higher costs, bid-rigging and bribery. A1

Are car alarms worth the headache? New York and other states mandate insurance discounts for cars with alarms, but many who have been woken up at 2 A.M. wonder why it is not public policy to outlaw them. A1

New York City's sliding economy now faces the decline of one of its last sources of strength: government spending and hiring. Mayor Dinkins's plans for layoffs could alter the city's reliance on public spending. B1

Security guards at the Meadowlands are the focus of a grand jury investigation. Cases of patrons being beaten-- plus the death of two rock fans since 1989 -- prompted allegations that the guards are too tough. B1
